9:02 This is why i don't like introductory(?) physics. We can literally get different answers by using different equations in the "4th big equations".  If we use the formula s(t)=1/2(a)(t), we would get s(5)=(-4.9)(5^2)= -122.5. Since distance is a scalar, then we can just remove the negative sign and get 122.5. Since the definition of speed is distance over time (speed=distance/time), then speed=122.5/5 = 24.5. This SHOULD be true because all i did was using the definition. However, the video uses velocity final and speed interchangeably, which also make sense to me. So which one is correct then?  Can somebody explain it to me why i got different answers?  EDIT: I'm 101% sure mine is correct since multiplying my answer by 5 will give the exact distance, while multiplying the video's answer by 5 would give a different distance (feel free to correct me btw).  I think the flaw in the video's answer is that it uses velocity and speed interchangeably. While sometimes it can be used interchangeably, but as we can see here that it doesn't work for this problem because the answer shows the velocity at that exact moment (velocity final), not the avg velocity.  Nonetheless, i still believe he's more knowledgeable than me.

Set an accelerometer at what you call  "rest" . It will be reading 9.8 m/s.  Now put it into freefall and it will read 0. Motion creates the buoyancy and density effects which cease to exist in freefall. You might want to start questioning and doing some simple observations if you're  going to be trying to teach.

because here, the ball is thrown Downward. Not upward. Remember this: objects going in the right or up direction, the velocity is positive. If objects are going left or down direction, the velocity is negative. That's why the velocity here is -15m/s not +15m/s. If the question said the ball is thrown (upwards) with an initial velocity of 15m/s, then the velocity would be +15m/s. But here the question is saying the ball is thrown (downwards), so that's why the velocity is -15m/s. Negative.

Imagine that you had a huge and tall room that is one mile high.   It is floating in outer space with two people inside.  One is located near the ceiling, and the other near the floor.   The room begins to head toward Earth with it being oriented such that the floor is closest to the Earth.  The rate at which the huge room is heading toward Earth is based upon the effects of Earths gravity across the entire room. The effect is greater at the floor area since it is closer to the Earth, but again its overall speed of approach is based upon the effects of gravity across the entire room. As a consequence of this, the person who was located near the floor, will begin to move toward the floor, and the person located near the ceiling, will begin to float closer to the ceiling. And so you could think of this a being two people inside a giant elevator. Hear, in this setting, it is clear that the effects of gravity will NOT simulate the effects of constant acceleration such as if the room was constantly accelerating out in space.
